abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            and sustainability is rated likely. The overall performances
            of both the Bank and the Borrower is rated satisfactory. As
            in the first Private Sector Development Project (PSD1), the
            main lessons learned from the PSD II relate to measures that
            could be adopted at project design to strengthen project
            implementation. They include recommendations regarding: (i)
            the inclusion of technical assistance components in credit
            lines approved in transition economies if long-term lending
            skills are largely underdeveloped in their banking systems;
            (ii) the establishment of independent implementation units
            with a formal agency arrangement; and (iii) choosing prudent
            banks capable of offering their clients a range of
            good-quality products and services. The selection criteria
            should rely largely on the sovereign prudential requirements
            as long as these have been deemed acceptable to the Bank.
            Other points elaborated in this ICR include: 1) The Bank
            should have a clear position on the level of interest rates
            to be offered to the financial intermediaries and final
            borrowers on its credit line funds. This position needs to
            take into account the fact that, in many countries which
            take out financial intermediary loans from the Bank, there
            are very few, if any, long-term funding sources in the
            financial system and no yield curves to speak of, thus
            rendering the pricing of such loans a discretionary matter
            agreed between the Bank and the Borrower (usually the
            Ministry of Finance). As a development institution, the Bank
            should consider passing along its low borrowing costs, not
            only to the official Borrowers but as an incentive also to
            the private sector participants. Continued availability of
            these long-term funds would catalyze the provision of
            medium- and long-term credits to private sector enterprises
            at reasonable rates, which would contribute to private
            sector-led growth. 2) Arrangements for usage of the repaid
            (revolving) funds after a project's formal closure
            should be agreed up front and ideally allow the funds to
            flow back into the participating financial intermediaries
            (PFIs) without strict conditions attached. 3) With regard to
            the conditions for using the funds during the project,
            procurement procedures continue to be perceived as too
            cumbersome by private sector enterprises. To this end,
            although the Bank has made substantial progress in
            simplifying it's procurement guidelines for private
            sector beneficiaries, attempts should be made to further
            streamline these procedures for the private sector without
            undermining the fiduciary responsibilities of the Bank.
